title: What Australia can learn from Anaheim
text:
Bright lights ... Anaheim’s best known as the home of Disneyland. Pic: Supplied. Source: Supplied Visit Anaheim promotional video 2:52 
The US city who's marketing boss thinks Australia needs to advertise more, shows us how it's done News Corp Australia 03 Sep 2015 Travel 
THE man responsible for promoting Anaheim, better known as the home of Disneyland, has dished out some timely advice for Australian tourism destinations — never stop advertising. 
Visit Anaheim CEO Jay Burress said the power of marketing could not be underestimated by the tourism industry which relied heavily on image to succeed. 
“If Vegas still has to advertise, everywhere has to advertise,” said Mr Burress during a whirlwind visit to Australia to promote his city which is part of Orange County . 
Anaheim welcomed 21.7 million visitors last year, up 16 per cent on the previous year. 
In comparison, 6.6 million people travelled to Australia in the year to June, up seven per cent. 
INSIDE THE $32K A NIGHT HOTEL IN AUSTRALIA Advantage ... Visit Anaheim concedes Disneyland helps the city attract more than 21 million visitors a year. Pic: AP/Damian Dovarganes Source: News Limited 
Mr Burress conceded Disneyland gave Anaheim an advantage when it came to attracting visitors, but he said there was a lot more to the city they wanted people to discover. and return to see. 
“We are here to help inspire the imagination of every visitor that comes to our destination, whether they’re a sports fan, adrenaline junkie, beach lover, theme park enthusiast or foodie,” Mr Burress said. 
Reinvention was another key strategy destinations should embrace, as well as community engagement. Another side to Anaheim ... Farmer’s Park is another attraction in the US city. Pic: Supplied. Source: Supplied 
In an effort to get the entire Anaheim community behind the tourism industry, Visit Anaheim recently ran a campaign highlighting what tourism taxes funded. 
“We told people if they didn’t want tourists coming to Anaheim, they would have to live without 20,000 street lights, the entire public library system and public parks,” Mr Burress said. 
“It’s these sorts of things the industry pays for and makes everyone’s lives better.” Popular ... Anaheim's Packing House — one of the groovy places to eat in the City, better known as the home of Disneyland. Pic: Supplied Source: Supplied 
Tourism and Transport Forum CEO Margy Osmond said she agreed Australia needed to do more to promote itself to the rest of the world. 
“TTF has been concerned to note the ($120 million) marketing funding budget for Tourism Australia has failed to keep pace with CPI for a number of years,” said Ms Osmond. 
“In the extremely competitive international tourism market, that funding shortfall is not sustainable if we are to continue to grow our share of the global visitor economy.” 
Figures out this week showed international visitor expenditure climbed ten per cent in the year to June, to $33.4 billion. 
“Our current performance in attracting international visitors is solid, but the reality is we could be doing so much better,” Ms Osmond said. 
TTF figures for 2013-14 showed the combined tourist marketing budget for Australia was $487 million.
